Allocating memory
You can allocate and deallocate memory for a program by calling proctal_allocate and proctal_deallocate, respectively.
The function proctal_allocate takes the size of the memory block. Here's how you would allocate 8 bytes in memory.
void *address = proctal_allocate(proctal, 8);
The function returns the address where the memory location starts. On error the address will have the value NULL and you can call proctal_error to find out what went wrong.
Access permissions can be defined by calling proctal_allocate_read_set, proctal_allocate_write_set and proctal_allocate_execute_set before proctal_allocate. By default all access permissions are set.
Once you are done using the memory block, you need to deallocate with proctal_deallocate. You just need to pass it the address you got from proctal_allocate.
proctal_deallocate(proctal, address);
